newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks close up, Hang Seng at 31-month high.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks close up, Hang Seng at 31-month high.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended firmer on Tuesday and the Hang Seng index hits its highest close since February 1994, buoyed by Wall Street's high and the view that a near-term rate hike would not hit stocks hard, brokers said.

"With precious little news on the domestic front, Hong Kong remains tied to the U.S. interest rate outlook -- which now looks limited to a 0.25 percent hike," said James Osborn, sales director at ING Barings.
The Hang Seng Index closed up 53.71 points, 0.46 percent, at 11,621.61, off an intra-day high of 11,645.35. The blue-chip barometer last closed higher at 12,157.57 on February 4, 1994.
Turnover was a healthy HK$7.05 billion, just shy of Monday's HK$7.56 billion, and borkers cited the rise in turnover as the single most bullish factor in the market on Tuesday.
"A lot of funds that are underweighted in Hong Kong were active, trying to participate in the market's gains," said Alvin Owyang, associate director at OCBC Securities.
Some cautioned buying activity was partly artificial, padded by the futures related buying of hedge funds. Others saw the market's limited advance on heavy turnover in fundamental terms.

"The index's hesitation at 11,600 (the previous 1996 intra-day high) suggests investors are confused about the correct valuation for the market," Osborn said. "We are still waiting to see how institutional funds will reallocate their Asian funds."
The Hang Seng pushed through 11,600 at the open but returned to waver around that level for most of the day.
The commercial and industrial index, which includes the territory's largest trading conglomerates, led the market rising 1.01 percent compared with the Hang Seng's gain of 0.46 percent.
Utility counters followed in a catching up exercise, having lagged the market for some time.
Swire Pacific was the star blue chip, gaining HK$1.00 to HK$69.50. Brokers said the share is benefitting from improved sentiment surrounding the residential property market.
Hutchison put on HK$0.70 to HK$49.80 and China Light added HK$0.20 to HK$34.50. HSBC was unchanged at HK$140.50.
China-incorporated H shares significantly underperformed the market with the Hang Seng Index Chinese Enterprise Index showing a decline of 0.47 percent.
Maanshan Iron rose HK$0.02 to HK$1.41, but Jingwei Textile fell HK$0.03 to HK$1.03 and Guangshen Rail dropped HK$0.07 to HK$2.925.
